case_name: Brij Bhushan v. Chief Commissioner of Delhi

facts.text: This is Original Jurisdiction Petition No. XXIX of 1950 filed as an application under article 32 of the Constitution for writs of certiorari and prohibition against the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. XXIX of 1950. Application under article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ of certiorari and prohibition. The facts are stated in the judgment.

facts.text: The first petitioner is the printer and publisher of the English weekly Organizer published in Delhi, and the second petitioner is its editor.

anchor.surface_text: examine the legality of and quash the order made by him in regard to an English weekly of Delhi called the Organizer of which the first applicant is the printer and publisher, and the second is the editor.

facts.text: On 2nd March 1950, the Chief Commissioner of Delhi issued an order under section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act 1949 extended to Delhi Province.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd March, 1950, the respondent, in exercise of powers conferred on him by section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, which has been extended to the Delhi Province and is hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act, issued the following order

facts.text: The Chief Commissioner of Delhi was satisfied that Organizer has been publishing highly objectionable matter constituting a threat to public law and order.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, is satisfied that Organizer, an English weekly of Delhi, has been publishing highly objectionable matter constituting a threat to public law and order and that action as is hereinafter mentioned is necessary

facts.text: The order requires the printer, publisher and editor of Organizer to submit for scrutiny before publication all communal matter and news and views about Pakistan including photographs and cartoons other than from official sources or specified news agencies.

anchor.surface_text: require you Shri Brij Bhushan, Printer and Publisher and Shri K.R. Halkani, Editor of the aforesaid paper to submit for scrutiny, in duplicate, before publication, till further orders, all communal matter and news and views about Pakistan including photographs and cartoons other than those derived from official sources or supplied by the news agencies, viz., Press Trust of India, United Press of India and United Press of America

facts.text: The case was argued before the Supreme Court with C. Chatterjee and B. Banerji for the petitioner, and C. Setalvad Attorney-General and S.M. Sikri for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee  B. Banerji, with him  for the petition- er. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General for India,  S. M. Sikri, with him  for the respondent.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on May 26 1950 by Patanjali Sastri J. for Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. May 26. The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri, Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was deliv- ered by Patanjali Sastri J.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate dissenting judgment, PATANJALI SASTRI J.

facts.text: Petitioners claim that section 7(1)(c) of the Act infringes the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a) and is not justified under clause (2).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners claim that this provision infringes the fundamental right to the freedom of speech and expression conferred upon them by article 19(1)(a) of the Constitu- tion inasmuch as it authorises the imposition of a restric- tion on the publication of the journal which is not justi- fied under clause (2) of that article.

facts.text: Imposition of pre-censorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is part of freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that the imposition of precen- sorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19(1)(a).

facts.text: The Supreme Court quashed the impugned order of the Chief Commissioner dated 2nd March 1950 and allowed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commission- er, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

facts.text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act 1949 was passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: section 7(1)(c) of the impugned Act which, as appears from its preamble, was passed to provide special measures to ensure public safety and maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Section 7(1)(c) empowers the Provincial Government or authorized authority, if satisfied necessary for preventing or combating activity prejudicial to public safety or public order, to require submission for scrutiny of matter relating to a particular subject before publication.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7(1)(c) under which the aforesaid order purports to have been made reads  so far as material here  as follows -- The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if satisfied that such action is neces- sary for the purpose of preventing or combating any activity prejudicial to the public safety or the maintenance of public order may, by order in writing addressed to a print- er, publisher or editor require that any matter relating to a particular subject or class of subjects shall before publication be submitted for scrutiny.

facts.text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act 1949 was passed by the Provincial Legislature under section 100 of Government of India Act 1935 read with Entry 1 List II Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, of which sec- tion 7 is a part, was passed by the Provincial Legislature in exercise of the power conferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, is read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which includes among other matters public order.

facts.text: Delhi Province has been notified as a dangerously disturbed area under section 20 of the East Punjab Public Safety Act 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It may be incidentally mentioned that we have been informed that, under this section, Delhi Province has been notified to be a dangerously disturbed area.

facts.text: The court decision in this case is based on the judgment in Petition No. XVI of 1950 Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: As this question turns on considerations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 2  was based, our judgment in that case concludes the present case also.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. holds that section 7(1)(c) is saved by article 19(2) as it relates to matters undermining security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the law which is impugned is fully saved by article 19(2) and if it cannot be successfully assailed it is not possible to grant the remedy which the petitioners are seeking here.

facts.text: The impugned order names Shri Brij Bhushan as Printer and Publisher and Shri K.R. Halkani as Editor.

anchor.surface_text: I, Shankar Prasad, Chief Commissioner, Delhi, do by this order require you Shri Brij Bhushan, Printer and Publisher and Shri K.R. Halkani, Editor of the aforesaid paper

facts.text: The scrutiny under the order is to be submitted to the Provincial Press Officer or in absence to Superintendent of Press Branch at 5 Alipur Road Civil Lines Delhi between 10am and 5pm on working days.

anchor.surface_text: to the Provincial Press Officer, or in his absence, to Superintend- ent of Press Branch at his office at 5, Alipur Road, Civil Lines, Delhi, between the hours 10 a.m. and 5 p.m. on work- ing days.

facts.text: The Chief Commissioner issuing the order is Shankar Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: I, Shankar Prasad, Chief Commissioner, Delhi, do by this order

facts.text: The order is till further orders.

anchor.surface_text: before publication, till further orders, all communal matter

facts.text: Petitioners pray to quash the order made on 2nd March 1950.

issues.text: Is section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 constitutionally valid?

anchor.surface_text: The only point argued before us relates to the constitutional validity of section 7(1)(c) of the impugned Act

issues.text: Does section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 infringe the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a)?

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners claim that this provision infringes the fundamental right to the freedom of speech and expression conferred upon them by article 19(1)(a)

issues.text: Is the imposition of pre-censorship a restriction on the liberty of the press included in Article 19(1)(a)?

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that the imposition of precensorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19(1)(a).

issues.text: Does section 7(1)(c), which authorises pre-censorship, fall within the permissible restrictions under clause (2) of Article 19?

anchor.surface_text: The only question therefore is whether section 7(1)(c) which authorises the imposition-of such a restriction falls within the reservation of clause (2) of article 19.

issues.text: Is section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 (as extended to Delhi) valid?

anchor.surface_text: FAZL ALI J.--The question raised in this case relates to the validity of section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 as extended to the Province of Delhi

issues.text: Does clause (2) of Article 19 save the impugned provision from invalidity?

anchor.surface_text: the only question which we have therefore to decide is whether clause (2) of article 19 stands in the way of the petitioners.

arguments.claim: Section 7(1)(c) of the East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949 infringes the fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a) and the restriction is not justified under clause (2)

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners claim that this provision infringes the fundamental right to the freedom of speech and expression conferred upon them by article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution inasmuch as it authorises the imposition of a restriction on the publication of the journal which is not justified under clause (2) of that article.

arguments.claim: Public safety denotes safety or security of the State

anchor.surface_text: This expression, though it has been variously used in different contexts (see the Indian Penal Code, Ch. XIV), has not acquired a well-recognized meaning in relation to an Act like the impugned Act, as a result of a long course of legislative practice, and may be taken to denote safety or security of the State.

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority held section falls outside Article 19(2)

arguments.claim: Public order and public safety are allied; public disorder covers small riots while public unsafety relates to insecurity of the State

anchor.surface_text: Thus public order and public safety are allied matters, but, in order to appreciate how they stand in relation to each other, it seems best to direct our attention to the opposite concepts which we may, for convenience of reference, respectively label as public disorder and public unsafety.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct, 1949  as extended to the Province of Delhi , which runs as follows - The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority decision applies Romesh Thappar without adopting this interpretation

arguments.claim: The Act provides special measures for serious cases affecting public safety or security of the State, not ordinary cases

anchor.surface_text: The prominence thus given to public safety strongly suggests that the Act was intended to deal with serious cases of public disorder which affect public safety or the security of the State, or cases in which...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct, 1949  as extended to the Province of Delhi , which runs as follows - The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if

arguments.claim: The Act is aimed at preventing public disorders that undermine the security of the State, thus falling within Article 19(2)

anchor.surface_text: If the Act is to be viewed as I have suggested, it is difficult to hold that section 7(1)(c) falls outside the ambit of article 19(2). That clause clearly states that nothing in clause (1)(a) shall affect the operation of any existing law relating to any matter which undermines the security of, or tends to overthrow, the State.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct, 1949  as extended to the Province of Delhi , which runs as follows - The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if

arguments.court_reasoning: Majority quashed relying on prior precedent

arguments.claim: Provisions of section 7(1)(c) are confined to a particular subject or class of subjects connected with public safety or maintenance of public order

anchor.surface_text: It should be noted that the provisions of sub-clause (c) are not in general terms but are confined to a particular subject or class of subjects, and that having regard to the context in which these words are used, they must be connected with public safety or the maintenance of public order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ct, 1949  as extended to the Province of Delhi , which runs as follows - The Provincial Government or any authority authorised by it in this behalf if

arguments.claim: The Act passed under power for public order which includes public tranquillity affecting the State

anchor.surface_text: The East Punjab Public Safety Act, 1949, of which section 7 is a part, was passed by the Provincial Legislature in exercise of the power conferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act, 1935, as read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which includes among other matters public order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity under pre-Constitution law accepted but overridden by Article 19

arguments.claim: The Act's provisions are intended for all cases of breaches of public order, small or grave

anchor.surface_text: The line of argument advanced on behalf of the petitioners is that since the Act has been passed in exercise of the power granted by the expression public order, used in the Government of India Act, which is a general term of wide import, and since it purports to provide for the maintenance of public order, its provisions are intended or are liable to be used for all cases of breaches of public order, be they small or insignificant breaches or those of a grave or serious nature.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n the section will be known.  1  1868 11 Cox c.c. 44.  2  1886 16 company 855.  8  74 A. There can be numberjustification for restricting the companyt

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrong angle; Act is special legislation for public safety

arguments.claim: Public safety and public order are disjunctive (separated by 'or'), covering ordinary cases

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that public safety and maintenance of public order are used in the Act disjunctively and they are separated by the word or and not and, and therefore we cannot rule out the possibility of the Act providing for ordinary as well as serious cases of disturbance of public order and tranquillity.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mers of the Constitution must have therefore found themselves face to face with the dilemma as to whether the word sedition should be used in article

arguments.court_reasoning: Narrow technical approach; allied concepts, dominant purpose public safety

holdings.text: The imposition of precensorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: There can be little doubt that the imposition of precensorship on a journal is a restriction on the liberty of the press which is an essential part of the right to freedom of speech and expression declared by article 19 1 a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court asserts with little doubt as foundational to freedom of speech analysis.

holdings.text: As pointed out by Blackstone in his Commentaries the liberty of the press consists in laying no previous restraint upon publications, and not in freedom from censure for criminal matter when published.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by Blackstone in his Commentaries the liberty of the press consists in laying no previous restraint upon publications, and not in freedom from censure for criminal matter when published.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Blackstone to define liberty of press as absence of prior restraint.

holdings.text: Section 7(1)(c) which authorises the imposition of such a restriction falls outside the reservation of clause (2) of article 19 as per decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The only question therefore is whether section 7 1 c which authorises the imposition-of such a restriction falls within the reservation of clause 2 of article 19. As this question turns on considerations which are essentially the same as those on which our decision in Petition No. XVI of 1950 2 was based, our judgment in that case concludes the present case also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same considerations as Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras govern; prior judgment conclusive.

holdings.text: We allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Romesh Thappar decision to facts warrants quashing.

holdings.text: The law which is impugned is fully saved by article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the law which is impugned is fully saved by article 19(2) and if it cannot be successfully assailed it is not possible to grant the remedy which the petitioners are seeking here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public safety equates to security of State; Act targets serious disorders undermining State security within Art 19(2).

holdings.text: Public safety may be taken to denote safety or security of the State.

anchor.surface_text: This expression, though it has been variously used in different contexts (see the Indian Penal Code, Ch. XIV), has not acquired a well-recognized meaning in relation to an Act like the impugned Act, as a result of a long course of legislative practice, and may be taken to denote safety or security of the State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretive equation based on legislative and judicial usage including Defence Acts.

holdings.text: The provisions of sub-clause (c) are confined to a particular subject or class of subjects... they must be connected with public safety or the maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: It should be noted that the provisions of sub-clause (c) are not in general terms but are confined to a particular subject or class of subjects, and that having regard to the context in which these words are used, they must be connected with public safety or the maintenance of public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading in context limits scope to public safety/order matters.

precedents.citation: Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras, supra p. 594.

anchor.surface_text: Romesh Thappar v. The State of Madras, supra p. 594.

precedents.case_name: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: constitutional validity of restrictions on freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(2); pre-censorship not justified

precedents.citation: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison

anchor.surface_text: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison 1 . The headnote of this case runs as follows By section 1 of the Defence of the Realm  Consolidation  Act, 1914, power was given to His Majesty in Council during the continuance of the present war to issue regula- tions for securing the public safety and the de- fence of the realm --  1  1920 2 K.B. 305.

precedents.case_name: Rex v. Governor of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison
precedents.cited_proposition: "public safety" includes prevention of internal disorder and rebellion, not limited to protection against foreign enemies
precedents.cited_holding: regulations authorized were not limited to regulations for the protection of the country against foreign enemies, but included regulations designed for the prevention of internal disorder and rebellion

precedents.citation: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King

anchor.surface_text: Niharendu Dutt Majumdar v. The King 1  which has been quoted again and again and in which Gwyer C.J. laid down that public disor- der, or the reasonable anticipation or likelihood of public disorder, is the gist of the offence of sedition and the acts or words complained of must either incite to disorder or  1  1942 F.C.R. 38.

precedents.cited_proposition: gist of sedition is public disorder or reasonable anticipation or likelihood thereof; acts/words must incite disorder or have that tendency
precedents.cited_holding: public disorder, or the reasonable anticipation or likelihood of public disorder, is the gist of the offence of sedition

anchor.surface_text: Fitzgerald J. in R.v. Sullivan  1 , and he also added that he was content to adopt the words of that learned Judge which are to be found in every book dealing with this branch of the criminal law.  1  1868 11 Cox c.c. 44.

precedents.cited_proposition: observations on the law of sedition

anchor.surface_text: Cave J. in his charge to the jury in a case relating to the law of sedition JR. v. Burns 2  said -- The law upon the question of what is seditious and what is not is to be found stated very clearly in a book by Stephen J. who has undoubtedly a greater knowledge of crimi- nal law than any other Judge who sits upon the Bench,  2  1886 16 company 855.

precedents.cited_proposition: Stephen's statement on sedition approved by judges

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Sadhashiv Narayan Bhalerao

anchor.surface_text: Privy Council, dealing with a case under the Defence of India Rules, expressed the view in King Emper- or v. Sadhashiv Narayan Bhalerao 3  that the test laid down by the learned Chief Justice was not applicable in India where the offence under section 124A of the Indian Penal Code should be construed with reference to the words used in that section.  3  74 A.

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v. Sadashiv Narayan Bhalerao
precedents.cited_proposition: sedition under s.124A IPC does not require incitement to disorder; to be construed by words of the section, not English common law
precedents.cited_holding: acts or words complained of must not necessarily incite to disorder or have that tendency; marginal note 'sedition' not operative

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, for the reasons indicated in that judgment, we allow this petition and hereby quash the impugned order of the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, dated the 2nd

outcome.relief_summary: Petition allowed; impugned order dated 2nd March 1950 quashed
directions: quash the impugned order of the Chief Commissioner, Delhi, dated the 2nd March, 1950
